'Marie Taquet-Martens' (1898-1989) and 'Ãmile Taquet' (1893-1971) were a husband
and wife team who saved Jewish children from the Holocaust. She was born in
Luxembourg in 1898; they married around 1918. [http://www.raoulwallenberg.net/?en/saviors/women/2997/marie-
taquet-belgium.3244.htm/ International Raoul Wallenberg Foundation
website] (This would make her in her forties during World War II.) ht-
tp://db.yadvashem.org/righteous/family.html?language=en&itemId=4021706

They ran a residence for children in Belgium, and hid significant numbers of
Jewish children among the general population of the school.

One source describes the residence as a school for the
children of Belgian military families, and her husband as a Belgian Army
officer. That account says that he was the school's administrator, and she the
headmistress.("Rescuers" repeats these facts.) It says that
the Gestapo visited. It calls the school "Reine Elizabeth Castle" (Reine meaning
"Queen"), and places it in Jamoigne, Belgium.

Another source [http://www1.yadvashem.org/odot_pdf/Microsoft%20Word%20-
%206742.pdf Shoah Resource Center/ Yadvashem.org] describes the residence
as a home for disabled children, which does not preclude it from being a home/
school for the children of Belgium officer's children. This source calls it the
Queen Elisabeth Home, and says it was in the Chateau du Faing, in the village of
Jamoigne-sur-Semois. The castle was said to belong to the Sisters of Charity of
Besancon. In "Rescuers", with an interview with Mrs Taquet,
1988, the school is described as "the Castle of Jamoigne, a school for boys
whose fathers were in the military." It also says "at least 80 Jewish boys
regard her as the woman to whom they own their lives".

A resource for teachers on the University of South Florida's
site [http://fcit.usf.edu/holocaust/People/Rescuer.htm/ Resource for
teachers, University of South Florida] says that the couple protected 80
Jewish boys.

Mrs Taquet died in September 1989, having been in a nursing home outside
Brussels just before that. Rescuers: Portraints of Moral
Courage in the Holocaust, Gay Block and Malka Drucker, ISBN 0-8419-1322-6

The story of their brave actions was the subject of the 1988 TV drama "Rescuers:
Stories of Courage", the Marie Taquet episode. (There were two episodes in the
series). It starred Linda Hamilton (of "Terminator" fame)as Marie Taquet, Alfred
Molina as her husband. It was directed by Lynne
Littman. [http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0156018/ IMDB entry for the
film] One source gives her name as Maria Taquet-Martens.

The castle stayed open until June 1946 because many of the parents of the Jewish
children did not return.
